column5: Jig and a minnow or a jig and a minnow or a jig and a minnow or every once in a while, a jig and a crawler/leech. (get the picture)
[font color=green size=3][b]Trolling a spinner and minnow, using a 3/8 bullet sinker in front of the swivel.
For Canada, a jig and minnow have worked wonders for our group each year. We will do some light casting with rapalas and wally divers, but Jig and minnow gets the best results
What is everyones favorite way to catch eyes?
Day 1 of the trip, when I am rested and feeling great, I like to work jig and minnow. Day 6 of the trip, when I am tired and hung over, I like to throw out a slip bobber or two, sit back and relax.
Corner of the mouth. Catch and Release the Big Ones so somebody else has a chance to catch there DREAM FISH.
Jigging -- hands down. But, it is not always the most productive technique.
I perfer jigging for them. If not that maybe trolling crankbaits. Mike
fishing the fast water below power dams 3-way 3oz wieght and a floating rap

My favorite way is whatever is most effective at a given time. I know that doesn't really answer your question, so here it goes. First, would be casting crankbaits, but that isn't always the most productive. Second would be casting and working jigs. Third would be the traditional type of jigging. Fourth would be a tie between bottom bouncing and trolling crankbaits. Next time you are bottom bouncing with a worm harness and are getting pestered by perch, try putting on a small floating rap instead of the worm harness. Cuts down on the mess with the worms, eliminates a lot of the perch problems, and seems to catch just as many eyes.
